be a response to the filing of that on March 2nd.
I'll talk only about two more issues. One is, briefly, some First Amendment cases that
we're involved in. We find that a number of gay community newspapers, like here in San
Francisco, we have the Bay Area Reporter, are being censored at a number of prisons
around the country. Prisons that want to keep in touch with their gay communities are not
being allowed to read these papers. So we're going to be involved in a suit probably, and
we're lucky, the Congressional Correctional Institute in San Francisco.
In Kentucky, and maybe one here at the Lompoc Prison, and possibly one down in Texas, as well.
And then the last thing that I want to talk about is the rights of gay students. I went
to, well, I went to several undergraduate schools, but I graduated from Michigan State
University, which is where I first got involved in gay political causes. And as a student,
I brought a suit against me.
I went to Michigan State University for refusing to allow us to place a banner on the two
official posts, shall we say, of the university where you can announce events. And Michigan
State University is on the main thoroughfare with 40,000 cars a day pass through this intersection.
We wanted to put a banner that said, Gay Pride Week, and the administration wouldn't let us.
So we filed an action against the university. We didn't win, but it was probably because
we weren't adequately prepared, because we found out from sort of some of our friends
that we were gay. And so we went to the University of Michigan State University, and we went
to the University of Michigan State University, and we went to the University of Michigan State
Institute. And in that case, they had to...
They had to report, you know, we were the first source of support to the administration
that they had been warned by their lawyers not to do that again next year. Because they
had probably been in some pretty serious trouble.
And so the next year, we made an application to put up the banner, and we went out without
any problems.
Now this same school, sitting in a city that has an anti-discrimination ordinance, which
I helped lobby for in 1971...
Last year, they allowed gay students to be kicked out of fraternities because they were
gay.
So, even though you have an anti-discrimination ordinance, it's not going to be worth a whole lot if it's not enforced.
So, there are continuing problems going on.
We found that there's a school, another school in Michigan called Andrews College, which is trying to kick out two students because they alleged they were gay.
There's a private college in the suburb of Chicago that once granted a bachelor's degree to a student who's completed all of his coursework and said this person's gay
because of the immoral character requirements of our school and he can't handle his degree.
We find that the University of Arkansas in Batesville, the school has official, granted official university recognition to the student organization there,
but they won't grant them any office space or any funding or any of the benefits that might go along with official recognition.
There's two cases going on in Texas right now,
involving the University of Arkansas.
They're asking students to get recognition at their campus.
And my last big gay rights case before I came to the West Coast involved a lawsuit against Georgetown University in Washington, D.C.
because they would not grant recognition to the undergraduate and to the law school gay student organizations.
So, there are still a lot of lawsuits involving students as well as many other areas that are important.
We can become complacent here in California.
It doesn't have a sodomy statute anymore.
We have a lot of protections.
People to a great extent are maybe a lot more relaxed.
They're used to hearing about seeing a gay community as sort of this old hat.
But in most parts of the country, there's still a lot of problems.
And that's what National Gay Rights Advocates is all about.
It's writing these new laws about diversity in the country.
Is Gay Rights Advocates taking on any cases involving gay youth?
Is it involving gay youth and their rights to their sexuality that have not been treated and considered?
Because that seems to be something in California that is sort of an issue.
And it's very hard to consider.
Yeah, there's a lot of problems in that area.
We have not taken on any cases involving that issue.
I can't say we've been presented with any.
What we do in determining what cases to take is we basically wait for people to come to us,
which is not much of an issue.
We don't have to get calls every day.
If a day doesn't go by, they don't get at least one call,
so then they can think about some kind of discrimination or adverse action.
But that particular issue hasn't reached us yet.

screenwriters have been pointing out that this city, Denver,
has a law that says two unrelated individuals cannot live together.
And this is often used against gay couples.
Yeah.
Yeah.
Yeah.
We haven't had any complaints in a long time about that kind of problem.
That is a way of certainly discriminating against gay people without being so forthright
as saying that we're not going to allow two gay people to live together.
The history of that kind of legislation I'm not so sure was necessarily anti-gay,
but was intended to keep noise down
and to protect sort of family-type environments.
But it certainly didn't have an impact on gay people.
In some areas like that, it's very subtle with legislation.
In some states like Virginia, it's very blatant.
